title: Box–ironbark forest
text:
Box–ironbark forest is a forest or woodland <a href="ecosystem">ecosystem</a> that is largely limited to central <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a> in south-eastern <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. Because its component tree species produce abundant nectar and pollen throughout the year, it is important for the conservation of many species of birds and other animals.
History.
Because box–ironbark forest lies mainly within the <a href="Goldfields%20region%20of%20Victoria">Goldfields region of Victoria</a>, during the main years of the <a href="Victorian%20gold%20rush">gold rush</a> (1851-1870) it underwent intensive digging and clearing in the goldfields, accompanied by extensive timber cutting for infrastructure and firewood in surrounding areas. After the gold rush subsided the forests were still heavily cut for firewood and cleared for pasture.
Description.
Box–ironbark forest is found on rocky, often auriferous (<a href="gold">gold</a>-bearing), soils, in flat and undulating landscapes at altitudes of 150–600 m above sea level, and with an average annual rainfall of 500–800 mm. About 40% of the area formerly supporting the ecosystem in Victoria is public land with less than 20% protected in conservation reserves. About 55% has been permanently cleared for <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a>, <a href="mining">mining</a> and <a href="urban%20development">urban development</a>. Remaining forest has been fragmented.
Vegetation.
Box–ironbark forest is characterised by a canopy of box, <a href="ironbark">ironbark</a> and gum-barked <a href="eucalypt">eucalypt</a>s, growing to 25 m in height, over a sparse understorey of <a href="Acacia">wattles</a>, small-leaved and prostrate <a href="shrub">shrub</a>s, <a href="herbaceous%20plant">herbs</a> and <a href="grass">grass</a>es. The main trees are <a href="Eucalyptus%20macrocarpa">white box</a>, <a href="Eucalyptus%20polyanthemos">red box</a>, <a href="Eucalyptus%20tricarpa">red ironbark</a>, <a href="Eucalyptus%20sideroxylon">mugga ironbark</a>, <a href="Eucalyptus%20leucoxylon">yellow gum</a> and <a href="Eucalyptus%20macrorhyncha">red stringybark</a>. In some areas they may grow with, or be replaced by, <a href="Eucalyptus%20melliodora">yellow box</a>, <a href="Eucalyptus%20goniocalyx">long-leaf box</a> or <a href="Eucalyptus%20nortonii">silver bundy</a>. The mix of plants in the groundcover includes the largest concentrations of <a href="orchid">orchid</a>s of any Victorian ecosystem. Small herbs and shrubs most abundant in, or largely restricted to, box–ironbark forests include "<a href="Cheiranthera%20cyanaea">Cheiranthera cyanaea</a>", "<a href="Philotheca%20verrucosa">Philotheca verrucosa</a>", "<a href="Xerochrysum%20viscosum">Xerochrysum viscosum</a>", "<a href="Pultenaea%20largiflorens">Pultenaea largiflorens</a>", "<a href="Acacia%20williamsonii">Acacia williamsonii</a>" and "<a href="Stuartina%20muelleri">Stuartina muelleri</a>".
Animals.
Because the trees of the box–ironbark forest are such prolific <a href="flower">flower</a>ers and <a href="nectar">nectar</a> producers, they are a major source of nectar and <a href="pollen">pollen</a> for <a href="honeyeater">honeyeater</a>s, <a href="lorikeet">lorikeet</a>s and many kinds of <a href="invertebrate">invertebrate</a>s. Flowering of the different species of eucalypts takes place at different times of year so there is always a nectar or pollen source available for <a href="bird%20migration">migratory</a>, nomadic and resident birds. Consequently, there are both more species, and greater numbers of individuals, of honeyeaters and lorikeets than in any other ecosystem. Nectar and pollen feeding birds such as the <a href="black-chinned%20honeyeater">black-chinned</a>, <a href="regent%20honeyeater">regent</a>, <a href="fuscous%20honeyeater">fuscous</a> and <a href="brown-headed%20honeyeater">brown-headed honeyeater</a>s, <a href="Swift%20parrot">Swift parrot</a>s and <a href="musk%20lorikeet">musk lorikeet</a>s are all more abundant in box–ironbark forests than elsewhere. The ecosystem supports the largest numbers of <a href="eastern%20grey%20kangaroo">eastern grey kangaroo</a>s in Victoria and is a stronghold for <a href="brush-tailed%20phascogale">brush-tailed phascogale</a>s, <a href="yellow-footed%20antechinus">yellow-footed antechinus</a>es and <a href="squirrel%20glider">squirrel glider</a>s.
